descriptionModule.briefSummary: The main purpose of this trial is to determine whether Xingnaojing, intravenously administered within 24 hours of symptom onset, improves the daily living ability of acute ischemic stroke at 90 days.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: The XMAS-2 study is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial. The primary hypothesis of this trial is that Xingnaojing will improve the daily living ability of acute ischemic stroke at 90 days. Xingnaojing will be compared to placebo, combined with guidelines-based standard care in patients with acute ischemic stroke within 24 hours of symptom onset. All participants will have a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale(NIHSS)entry score of 4-25. Participants who have planned or already received the intravenous thrombolysis or endovascular treatment will be excluded. The primary outcome will be determined at 90 days.

armGroups.label: Xingnaojing
armGroups.description: Subjects will receive intravenously administered Xingnaojing injection, combined with guidelines-based standard care.

armGroups.label: Placebo
armGroups.description: Subjects will receive intravenously administered Xingnaojing placebo, combined with guidelines-based standard care.

interventions.name: Xingnaojing injection
interventions.description: Xingnaojing injection (20 ml)+0.9% diluted sodium chloride injection 250ml, IV (in the vein), every 12 hours for 10 days.

interventions.name: Xingnaojing placebo injection
interventions.description: Xingnaojing placebo injection (20 ml)+0.9% diluted sodium chloride injection 250ml, IV (in the vein), every 12 hours for 10 days.

interventions.name: Standard care
interventions.description: Guidelines-based standard care for acute ischemic stroke.

primaryOutcomes.description: Proportion of patients independent is defined as Modified Rankin Scale score of 0, 1, or 2.The Modified Rankin Scale Score ranges from 0 (best score) to 6 (worst score).

secondaryOutcomes.description: The early neurologic deterioration is defined as an increase of 1 points or more in the National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score between baseline and 3 days. The NIHSS score ranges from 0 (best score) to 42 (worst score).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Neurological impairment evaluated by National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS).
secondaryOutcomes.description: Comparison of the change in the NIHSS scores from baseline to 10 days in the two groups.The NIHSS score ranges from 0 (best score) to 42 (worst score).
Patient reported outcome (PRO) scale of stroke at 10 days.The PRO score ranges from 36(best score) to 180 (worst score).
The state of consciousness evaluated by Glasgow Coma Scale at 7 days. The Glasgow score ranges from 3(worst score) to 15 (best score).
Activities of daily living will be measured by Barthel Index score at 30 days and 90 days.The Barthel Index score ranges from 0 (worst score) to 100 (best score).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: The proportion of patients independent at 30 days.
secondaryOutcomes.description: The proportion of patients independent will be evaluated by mRS at 30 days.The mRS score ranges from 0 (best score) to 6 (worst score).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: The recurrence rate of cerebrovascular events
secondaryOutcomes.description: The recurrence rate of cerebrovascular events within 90 days.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Stroke related deaths and deaths from any cause
secondaryOutcomes.description: Stroke related deaths and deaths from any cause within 10 days and 90 days after symptom onset.
Number of patients with any adverse events, results of electrocardiography, vital signs and laboratory tests (complete blood count, chemistry and urinalysis).
